Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, reading Priya’s message: “Let’s go out Thursday night? We finally have time!” My heart leapt. We’d both been so busy, and I missed our long talks and laughter. Thursday was perfect—except it was also the night of my cousin’s puja, a family ceremony I was expected to attend. My parents had already reminded me to be home early, to help set up and wear my kurta. They’d be disappointed if I skipped it, especially since family gatherings are so important in our tradition.

But Priya was excited, already suggesting places we could go. I could almost hear her voice, hopeful and happy. I wanted to be with her, to show her she mattered. Yet, I also felt the weight of my family’s expectations, the importance of honoring our customs. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of Priya’s company and the duty I felt toward my family and faith. The two worlds pulled at me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to both at once. I stared at my phone, unable to type a reply, caught in the tension of choosing between love and tradition.
